description.text:
This is a model of my cat, sleeping on a pillow. It is intended to fit onto one of PrettySmallThings' lovely chairs or sofas.
I made about thirty pictures, stitched in Catch123, then modified in Meshmixer.

I've been printing this as large as possible on my Thingomatic (in ABS) to test detail of rendering. If scaled to fit on a PrettySmallThings' (http://www.thingiverse.com/PrettySmallThings) chair it will likely look like a small lump on a bigger lump. But then, that's kind of what my cat looks like while sleeping away the day.

A 3d model of a Hérens cow.
Hérens cows are found in Wallis (in Switzerland), originating from the Valley of Hérens.

If someone can prepare the model to be printed by FDM printers, please share as a remix!
I could generate them but not as a single shell in meshmixer and simplify 3d has a lot of trouble dealing with meshmixer supports if they are not "fused" together!

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Formlabs Form 2

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

50 microns

Infill:

hollow

Notes:

There are two files, one full and one hollow (made for printing in 10 cm in the largest dimension).
The model was successfully printed on other resin printers.

Using a handheld 3d scanner we scanned a cow as good as possible.
Then as we could only gather partial scans (cows doesn't like to be 3d scanned apparently!) the final model was recomposed and details were added.

DISCLAIMER: Not a functioning case.
Its really impractical actually, but it looks kinda nice in a photo at least. First off, It is very difficult to remove the supports from inside the case.
Secondly, well it just doesn't fit. It is too small. I attempted to heat it with a blow dryer then stretch it but it just warped it. I got it to hold long enough to take the photo basically. Also, the lip that is supposed to clip it to the front of the iPhone is week and breaks off the sides completely. All that being said, eh, what can you expect from a hard plastic case. My hopes weren't too high to begin with.

-I subtracted 4 additional holes from the original case to make them look like bubbles using Rhinoceros.
-The seahorse was printed separately then super glued in place (I found it on thingiverse too).
-It was all printed on a Maker Bot Replicator 2 in white, then painted with acrylic. **Would not recommend printing this again without scaling it up some to help it fit the phone better.

title: Gravity
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Gravity is a playful mechanical scales for cooking, inspired by ancient scales, it rests on a principle of cantilever and balance.

Its use is very simple, to weigh an ingredient it is enough to deposit it in its receptacle, then move horizontally the counterweight until reaching the point of equilibrium of the balance, indicated by a level with bubble. The weight in grams in front of the counterweight then corresponds to the mass of the ingredients poured into the receptacle.

It is a playful object with an assumed aesthetics, to find a forgotten object designed and designed in a contemporary way.
Gravity can be an educational object for children who learn to cook ...

Gravity is composed of parts mainly printed in 3D and two parts of playwood (5mm thickness) cut by laser or scroll saw (contact me for the 2D file)

For more information you can consult the site under development:

http://www.cromagnon.xyz/

Do not hesitate to contact me to submit your ideas, to have more details on the assembly of the product (s) ...

title: Solar eclipse photography filter holder for Baader AstroSolar filter, fits 85mm diameter lens

description.text:
Observing and imaging a solar eclipse requires special filters to protect eyesight, lenses and cameras. The filters ready available are mounted in plastic or aluminum. These filters are attached like lens caps to the front of the gear used.
During a total solar eclipse, the filter may be removed for the short time of totality, when Baily's Beads, diamond ring effect or only the corona are visible. When shooting an eclipse it is always a bit of a hazzle to remove the filter when totality is finally visible and reattach the filter when the sun reappears.
To facilitate this, I created this filter holder, to mount Baader AstroSolar mylar filter to different lenses. This filter holder provides the flexibility to allways keep the filter at the front of the lens. Just flip away the filter when needed, or even cover the lens completely with the cover plate...

Filter fits 85mm lens barrels like Sigma 70-200mm 1:2,8

Parts required:
1x M4x50 screw
1x M4 nut
4x M4 washers (preferably teflon, polyamide, ...)
6x 2,9mmx6,5mm screws
optional 2x 8x1mm round neodymium magnets
1 round cut out of Baader AstroSolar filter foil

HINT
During tests on a hot day, when the filter was exposed to mid-day sun for a few hours, the cover piece printed in black material did warp. Therefore I recommend to coat primarily the cover plate with aluminium foil (use spray glue) or with chrome effect paint to reduce the heat build up during partial phase! Pay attention to paint the whole surface evenly and filling all gaps, ridges, ...

title: Anet A8 Y assembly Prusa like

description.text:
Bienvenue,

ce design permet de remplacer l'axe Y en plexi par un chassis largement inspiré de la prusa i3 originale. Le montage est facile et peu couteux, j'ai pu réutiliser la totalité des pièces métalliques du chassis original, je me suis juste procuré 2 tiges filetés M10 et tous les écrous rondelles qui les composes.

AVANTAGES:
-peu couteux et totalement compatible avec l'aneth A8
-dans certains cas réduction des vibrations
-amélioration de la stabilité du lit chauffant
-possibilité de réglage précis de l'équerrage
-possibilité d'installer un lit chauffant plus profond en changeant les tiges lissent et les vis M10

INCONVENIENTS:
-ce n'en est pas un, mais il faudra agrandir les trous dans lesquels passent les tiges filetés M8 actuelles
-Il faudra remplacer la courroie par une plus longue

Welcome and sorry for my bad English,

This design is make to replace the axis Y acrylic made by a frame widely inspired of the Prusa i3. The assembly is easy and little expensive, I was able to reuse all of the metallic parts of the original frame, I just had to buy 2 M10 threaded rods and all the nuts washers that made them up.

PROS:

  • little expensive and full compatible with the Anet A8
  • in certain cases reduction of the vibrations
  • improvement of the stability of the heating bed
  • possibility of precise regulation of the squareness
  • possibility of installing a deeper heating bed by changing the smooth rods and install longer M10 threaded rods.

CONS:
-It is not one, but it will be necessary to enlarge the holes in which pass the current threaded rods M8
-You have to change your belt by a longer

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Choose your own infill but you'll need a strong print

Step 0 : Pré-requis / Requirements

2 x 410mm de tige fileté M10
2 x 280mm de tige fileté M10
2 x 280mm de tige fileté M8 (réutiliser celles d'origine)
22 écrous M10
22 rondelles M10
12 écrous M8
12 rondelles M8
12 vis M2 courtes
Colle cyanolite
1 foret de 10
1 foret de 8

2 x 410mm threaded rod M10
2 x 280mm of threaded rod M10
2 x 280mm threaded rod M8 (reuse original ones)
22 M10 nuts
22 washers M10
12 M8 nuts
12 M8 washers
12 short M2 screws
Cyanolite glue
1 drill of 10
1 drill of 8

Step 1 : Printing

Vous devez imprimer:
4 Smooth_rod_stops
2 Corner FL/RR
2 Corner FR/RL
et les 2 dernières pièces une seule fois.

Choisissez un remplissage assez important pour gagner en résistance mécanique.

You have to print:
4 Smooth_rod_stops
2 Corner FL / RR
2 Corner FR / RL
And the last 2 only once.

Choose a good infill to gain mechanical strength.

Final Step : Assembling

Il n'y a rien de compliquer, vous pouvez vous aider du manuel de montage de la prusa accessible à cette page pour assembler le chassis: https://prusa3d.dozuki.com/Guide/2.+Y-axis+assembly/298. Il faudra préalablement repasser un coup de foret dans les passages des tiges filetés des 4 pieds, ainsi qu'agrandir le passage des tiges M10 de 480mm dans le cadre original de l'anes. Pour finir vous devrez adapter les distances pour que votre lit chauffant soit accessible en tout point par votre buse. Le fin de course Y a été fixé à la colle cyanolite sur le pied arrière gauche.

There is nothing complicated, you can help you with the assembly manual of the prusa on this page: https://prusa3d.dozuki.com/Guide/2.+Y-axis+assembly/ 298. It will be necessary to drill a bit holes of the threaded rods in the 4 feet, as well as enlarge the passage of the 480mm threaded rods in the original frame of the Anet. Finally, you will have to adapt the distances so that your heating bed is accessible at all points by your nozzle. The Y limit switch has been glued to the cyanolite glue on the left rear foot.

I have designed this for my Dell Optiplex 390.

I wanted to install my large PCI GFX card into my new computer. The original HDD mount was in the way for the end of the card and it's power supply plugs.

This is designed to be mount to the inside of the case with 3mm (or larger) screws with a lower mount that rests on the inner casing.
The universal bracket is deigned to slot into other but will need gluing to make the parts solid.
I have designed a spacer for the HDD that will fit thinner 250GB drives and also larger 1 TB drives. This is a push fit but can be glued if needed.
The HDD are only secured by gravity and shouldn't fall out unless the case is turned on its side.

I only plan on fitting 2 HDD into the computer case due to space

The 3mm mount should be printed solid so you can drill out the hole to suit the thread size that you want to use. This then gets glued to the Universal Bracket
The bottom support gets glues to the lower of the 2 holes to help support the bracket against the computer case.
The spacer should then be printed and push fitted into the upper of the holes. The large spacer is for thinner drives (250GB) and the thin spacer is for larger drives (1TB)
The end bracket is to finish off. This will need gluing to the universal bracket.

0.2mm layer hight

Universal and end bracket both printed with 25% infill, using support on the universal bracket.
All other parts printed with 100% infill and support where needed.

I have printed in ABS.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.

I’ve been wanting to put some order in my stock bins.
My heavy-duty trays are great for storing parts, components, small tools and many other small items.
They are stackable but this is not very practical in everyday situations.
Garage racks are great but expensive and my stock bins are not designed to fit, only by themselves, in a pegboard.
With this thought in mind I’ve decided to design a plastic piece to allow my storage bins containers to be hanged.
My criteria for the design was the robustness, the cost and should be 3D printed.
So, I’ve designed this object Fusion 360.
You can see my 3d printer working in a set of five bin brackets here: https://youtu.be/tgdB4zH1qOo or see more photos in my blog www.legendaryurbanhacker.com

Airsoft M14 Socom muzzle adaptor to fit standard airsoft 14mm ccw-threaded muzzle accessories on.

title: Quick Release Plate for DOLICA AX620 B100

description.text: This is for my DOLICA AX620 B100 camera tripod. At 40 X 40 mm it was a little loose so I added a millimeter to the length and width. One end is contoured to fit the clamp. It only fits one way - contour to the clamp. It needs a 1/4-20 screw to secure it to a camera tripod mount. I couldn't find a short one at my local hardware store so I got a nylon screw and cut it to fit (about 3/8" long). I designed it in an older version of TurboCAD and printed it on an XYZprinting DaVinci 1.0.

title: Da Vinci PRO E3D V6 Carriage: Single/Dual Extrusion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
THIS IS THE FINAL VERSION! ((COMING SOON: ULTRA NARROW VERSION!!!!)
It uses LM8UU Bearings. The 4 holes are 15mm (14.95) diameter and 15mm wide!

NOTE: The END STOP tab works GREAT, and will need trimmed because it's too long, and ALSO, MAY NEED TO BE PAINTED WITH A PAINT MARKER to function properly so that light CANNOT pass through!

FIND US HERE and share info of your modded Da Vinci Printer!
https://www.facebook.com/groups/ProDuino/

FYI, this fits 8mm rails (with LM8UU bearings) spaced 70mm apart.
The rail track is horizontal.

SINGLE AND DUAL EXTRUSION CARRIAGES
for Da Vinci 1.0 / 2.0 ? / PRO Printers with a Bowden setup.
For 1 or 2 E3D V6 hotends
The SPACING BETWEEN DUAL HOTENDS is 25mm !
Dual Setups only work with Arduino/RAMPS setups, not with the original Pro board.

Requires 75-80mm x M3 bolts (quantity 2)
LM8UU bearings (x4)
ONE small zip tie to hold the belt to the carriage.
PLEASE PRINT ALL CLAMP PIECES "OPEN" SIDE UP!!!! ('U' on top)

A cooling fan of about 40-50mm should easily adapt to the front.... 12V for RAMPS 1.4 setups.

With the Dual E3D V6 setup, the left side is slotted, and Z-axis is adjustable in comparison with the fixed right side. Adjust before tightening.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Da Vinci Pro MODIFIED w/RAMPS 1.4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.300

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Just use 50% Infill... And NO Support needed!
Print as positioned, FRONT face down!

Cleanup the holes, but don't enlarge the holes for the bearings more than 15mm!!!

When the carriage is in place and moving freely, place some rubberized glue in the rear round hole to keep the bearing from sliding out and allow to dry.

Mount The End Stop Tab, then paint it with a paint marker if light passes through it! I couldn't get the optical sensors to work with White PETG until I painted it Silver. Trim the Tab (shorter and shorter) until it docks nicely all the way to the right side!
Designed with Fusion 360

comments.text: does this allow for the standard cooling shroud to fit without problem?  You have not provided any pictures of the thing actually assembled... how is anyone supposed to know if you have done anything more than put a e3d heat sync in the thing.  Good design, poor execution.  I will remix and make it proper including the allowance of bushings over bearings.  Why would you switch away from bushings when, A) They are already on the machine so you don't have to source new ones., and B) Bushings are the proper thing to use in this context, not bearings.  Bearings are only used because people don't have the skill required to have an accurate enough build to allow for bushings....bearings are more forgiving but not the correct application.  Or is this the reason that you used bearings?  Does the carriage you made stick when you try to slide it?  Anyways thanks for the step in the right direction.

title: The Perched Rock near Lee's Ferry, Arizona

description.text: This is a replica of the "Perched Rock" near Lee's Ferry and Marble Canyon, Arizona. It was first photographed by William Bell in 1872 as part of a USGS survey of the American West. A version of his original stereoscopic view is here: http://www.klettandwolfe.com/ImageDetails/BellsRock.jpg This model was derived from pictures I originally made for a "walk around" photo-animation: http://www.klettandwolfe.com/2010/12/a-walk-around-william-bells-perched-rock-lees-ferry-arizona.html The pictures were stitched in Catch123 then further modified in Meshmixer. The top of the rock isn't accurate as a result of my lack of expertise with Meshmixer. Other variations on the idea include a walk into the historic stereoscopic image: http://www.klettandwolfe.com/2009/10/a-walk-through-.html and a large scale stereoscopic panorama that requires a custom-built viewing device: http://www.klettandwolfe.com/ImageDetails/JumboStereoViewer.jpg
I printed this in PLA because the warping with ABS was severe. Even the PLA peeled up a little during printing. Printed with one shell.

This is a simple 3D printed desktop garden, 8.5" x 4.5" x 8.25". You'll need a pretty good 3D printer to to print this.This is a great project for a classroom or an office. Print with supports, rafts, and 20% infill. The filament is up to you but I recommend ABS.

How it works(Please read!)

The top chamber is for watering, which falls down to the grow chamber. There, you can add plants that don't have a lot of roots(i.e. grass or small herbs). The chamber at the top is for grow lights and the slot on the bottom is for seeing water levels.

Happy Growing!

Overview This is a great project for a classroom as a demonstration for growing simple plants and how plants need to do photosynthesis to make glucose and turning that into energy. 1 or 2 are recommended for each class but one can be in the office or library if schools are on a tight budget.

Lesson plan Show the students how to load the model onto the software and watch it print. Once it's done, fill the grow bed with soil and put some seeds in. Then put water in the top chamber, and if you want, put grow lights in the last chamber(on the inside of the ring at the top). Then make a list of all the students and have each of them water it on a specific day. Tell them how much to put in and where to do it. Then you can admire your GROW garden!

print_settings.Notes:: The model you see in the photos was printed at 0.30mm for a good mix of accuracy and speed.

description.text:
Puzzle Cube

This is an old puzzle that I remember being super frustrated with when I was younger. I tried looking for it online, but could not even find any reference to it anywhere. Same with thingiverse... so here it is.

Every piece is identical, so you can mix and match colors, and build them into a chain. Some pretty neat structures are possible. I am currently printing some more and will update the photos with some chained together.

The STL has one set of pieces. You will need to print three sets to complete one cube. Pieces are simple and easy to print. Everything locks together when the last piece is put in place. No glue required!

Thanks to Brandon12321 for reminding me this puzzle existed! His cube chain design sent me down memory lane: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430357

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.30mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Brim/Support

Overhangs arent bad. This probably prints better without supports. Less cleanup afterwards. Brim is highly recommended because the footprint of each piece is actually very small. I used 4mm and it held on nicely.

Material

I printed this in PETG. It flexes a bit more than PLA, so it makes assembly a bit easier. I may try a PLA version in the near future, or maybe somebody can try for me and post results.

Resolution

The model you see in the photos was printed at 0.30mm for a good mix of accuracy and speed.

Assembly

If there are enough requests, I may post a how to assemble video here... but try to figure it out on your own first?

Not that the design was difficult, but this was designed from scratch in Tinkercad from my childhood memories. The tolerances are still being ironed out. The semi-circle cutouts in the middle have to be the right size so that it's reasonably easy to put together, but still has small enough clearance to have a good pressure fit so that the assembled cube holds itself together well.

There is a very good chance that this is much bigger than the original toy (if anybody still has one!) since I was definitely smaller when I was playing with it.

comments.text: I'm pretty sure the puzzle you were thinking of was called 'Chain Reaction' -- I still have mine from way back when, and I recently found it in a box of old toys, so I've scanned in the instructions and uploaded them here: http://imgur.com/a/7xtTK

title: Pi Zero Case with Swivel Camera mount

description.text:
After setting up Octoprint on one of my 3D printers, I wanted to mount a camera to view print progress remotely. I played around with some of the Pi camera modules but found the lack of a hand operated focus annoying. After purchasing some with large adjustable lenses, I found there wasn't really much in terms of mounts on Thingiverse. So I decided to build my own that not only allowed me to mount such a camera, but also swivel it and also to mount it to the door of the 3D printer, so I could have a better front-on view and avoid the heat of the enclosed 3D printer. I always had them in the corner and found it gave quite a bad view of the print. Now that the Pi Zero W is supported by Octoprint, I could mount it all in a small lightweight package on the plexiglass door with minimal amounts of wiring.

What I've also done is powered it via the GPIO pins, as well as linking up a relay so I can switch the 3D printer on and off remotely. The usb cable is just for the printer interface. There is a gap left for the GPIO pins to be neatly tucked inside. Due to the direction of the camera cable, I had to mount the Pi Zero 'backwards', so the camera cable doesn't experience any twisting.

If your looking for the same camera, they are sold as 'night-vision' Pi cameras, but mine didn't include the infrared LEDs. I also needed a camera cable adapter, as the Pi Zero uses a smaller port.

This design utilizes push-in nuts. I do this on most of my mechanical designs, so you'll need a relatively well calibrated printer and I'd recommend printing in ABS due to its slight flexibility. To insert the nuts, I use a slightly larger screw and tighten it enough that it gets 'pulled' into the socket permanently.

You will need:
1 x Raspberry Pi Zero (I used v1.3 Pi Zero W)
1 x Pi Module camera (I designed this for the night vision version, but others may work)
1 x Camera cable adapter (If your not using the Pi Camera V2)
8 x M3 Nuts
8 x Counter Sunk M3 Screws (Length needs to be around 15mm for 4, and 10mm for 4, but you can use longer ones, but not shorter).

Attach the cable to the camera module THEN screw the camera parts together. When attaching the swivel mounts, do not over-tighten so you can still adjust it manually as per its purpose. The Pi can be mounted onto the back panel and placed straight on when finished.

I used I_am_me's design for the Pi specific parts. The back panel is purely his design, and the 'lid' was remixed into the main part of the frame of this design (So it's kind of backwards to his original design).

Enjoy!

title: cable drag chain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Remixed this because I needed a cable drag chain and didn't want to use the IGUS e-chain on the off chance that I release my CNC design to thingiverse or a site like thingiverse.

I wanted a cable chain that I could "close" using zip ties, and I had thought it needed to be around 3 cm in width maximum.

The design as posted by Captain_3d was nearly what I wanted.

To get the result I have I changed the zip tie attachment from being around pins on one side of the chain to being around the chain. It was my feeling that this allows for more space inside the chain for cables. The width has been changed to 3 cm. I replaced the existing attachment points on the outside of the start and end link with four counter sunk screw holes on the inside of these links. This reduces the over all width of the whole chain to be the same 3 cm which allows it to move unhindered in one version of a CNC design I was working with.

(Currently) Unpublished CNC design.

As mentioned above, I am currently designing a CNC mill. I'm undecided if I will post this to thingiverse, at this time. Comment below if a CNC using the MGN 9c rail would be interesting.

GoPro session mount.

Two editions, and multiple angle snap settings allow you to adjust the camera angle, and allow for compliance in the event of the crash which you totally won't have because you're a #dronePro, so that you don't shatter this into a million pieces.

Use zip ties to affix to your racer, and some foam or rubber to add vibration damping and snugness.

Three levels of camera security for three levels of people:

"Safety comes first and I love my GoPro" use the small attachment plate and 4 self tapping screws e.g. these fine examples of torx* superiority:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GDZ045M/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
to secure the absolute shit out of your precious camera.

"I just sort of want to pop the camera in and out really quickly" don't bother with the security plate, just let the flexible retention clip do its job. prepare to print multiples of this part, because the tab totally snaps off if you flex it about 0.05mm too far. You'll get the hang of it eventually.

"F*** having money" snap the tab off, don't use the security bar, do clockwise barrel rolls over deep water or cliffs. perhaps consider ditching your quadrotor in the deepest part of a lake after exhausting your supply of gopros, where it definitely will not form an artificial reef.

If you found this using "drone" and your quadrotor isn't capable of flying itself without your input, that word really does not mean what you think that word means.

*this product not guaranteed to work with any type of screw besides torx, or torx.

description.text:
3D Guardian is an ultimate 3D printer fire prevention device, with some extras.

The primary function of 3D Guardian is to constantly monitor the printer's environment, and to shut it down (sounding an alarm) if the environment moves beyond the trained range. In addition to the traditional sensors (temperature, smoke, CO), it has a unique feature - a heated bed resistance sensor, which constantly monitors the resistance (voltage and current) of the heated bed wiring. Problems with this wiring (bad connectors, broken wires) is probably the most common cause of 3D printer fires; all these issues will manifest themselves as an increased bed wiring resistance, and the printer will be shut down automatically way before the actual fire starts.

The secondary function of 3D Guardian is to control the exhaust system of the printer's enclosure. That includes operating the air inlet and outlet (with stepper motors), and PWM control of the exhaust fan.

The device can be operated directly (5-keys keypad + 2x16 LCD screen), or via WiFi from a smart phone. It uses standard smart home frameworks (MQTT and OpenHAB), and can be easily integrated into your smart home setup.

Some experience with DIY electronics is required.

The printable parts are the parts for the control unit (3d_guardian_top, 3d_guardian_bottom, one red_button and five copies of the black_button), and for the power unit (Power_unit_top, Power_unit_bottom, Power_unit_part). Both original (SketchUp) and STL files are provided. I printed everything in ABS with 100% infill and 0.2 mm layers.

Full details (including the user guide) can be found here: http://pulsar124.wikia.com/wiki/3D_Guardian

author: trailogy

description.text:
Still a work in progress, I'll update when I print and test some.  This is a z probe that uses the inherent springiness of a roller switch to push the probe back down and hold the probe in the "up" position after bed leveling.  
I will get some better picutres of it in action.  There is a small nylon spacer on the 3mm shaft that pushes up against the roller part of the switch and is pushed back down unless the probe is pushed past the wheel in which case it is held UP.  I originally thought a magnet might be needed

Insert 3mm shaft through the bottom hole (I had to ream it out slightly), attaching the nylon spacer on the other side.  Continue to push the rod through the top hole adjusting spacer position.  
position the switch and either drill holes to mount it or tack it in place (I just used hot glue so that I could try a few different positions.)  The hieght of the probe can be adjusted somewhat by moving the spacer,  You want it low enough that the shaft is still inserted into the top hole while the spacer is at the bottom of the mount but high enough on the rod to keep the hotend from crashing.

title: Tevo Tarantula X Carriage RJ45 Breakout Mount

description.text:
This bracket lets you mount 2 RJ45 Breakout boards onto my MGN12H X carriage. (See photos) They are specifically for the MDFLY RJ45 breakout. You can get them on Amazon and probably also on eBay.

It is designed to be as far back as possible so that it doesn't cut build height. The breakouts are also mounted high enough to allow the use of ferrules.

I'm working on a similar bracket using an HDMI breakout. That will give 20 wires on a single connector instead of only 16 possible with 2 ethernet cables. Stay tuned!

description.text:
Hello everyone, I am very happy to have finished this ChipE casing design with a softer and fluffier style, add interchangeable heads and super cool articulated arms. I hope you like it. #ChipERemix
This design is a remix of "Chip-E" by Robot Geek
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795648

Arms are a remix of "Articulated Jellyfish" by 3DCentralVA
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1692607

Printrbot

Printer:

Play

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2

Infill:

15-25%

Notes:

I recommend to make some test prints to know if the parameters of your printer allow to manufacture the pieces without support material

I designed this robot based on the internal dimensions of the robot "Chip-E" but with an appearance that mixed a somewhat Japanese aesthetic like the Gundam robots in conjunction with my personal style, looking for it to look cool, at the same time sturdy and smooth. Everything was designed using surfaces in Rhinoceros 5.
Now I will describe some peculiarities of the pieces designed:
The HEAD was the most significant change, has the possibility to interchange with other heads that later I will design, but more importantly it contains the "RobotGeek IR Receiver". Using a speed between 20 and 30 mm / s will not require support material, the printing is vertical to improve the appearance of the piece.

As much as "MID, MID CAP and BASE" can be printed without material of support, a infill of 15% can be more than sufficient.

In the case of "UPPER" it is important to use support material but if you are not concerned about the interior quality you can experiment by avoiding the support material and using a bridge technique using the maximum fan speed.

In the case of ARMS you will have to apply a little force to release the links. This specific piece is a remix of www.thingiverse.com/thing:1692607

The HANDS can be printed without support material, however I advise to use "Brim" or "Raft" and in the last phases of the printing to maximize the speed of the fan or to use an external one to avoid deformation of the tips of the fingers .

I hope you enjoy printing this as I did it by designing. :)

This description was translated using Google Translate, I regret the grammatical errors

comments.text: Thanks,

description.text:
This WhizWheel is used to visualize a satellite in orbit based on the common orbital elements (COEs). The first five COEs (defined below) are assumed to be fixed for simple orbital motion. Once once you visualize those parameters, you've successfully simulated the orbit any given satellite is flying in. I printed this example at 120% the original size. I have created a plastic pin to hold the orbit onto the center of the orbital plane. A screw can also be used to attach the orbit as shown. The pin, or screw, represents the Earth at a focus of the orbit.

To visualize a satellite in orbit, you'll need the following COEs (a,e, i, RAAN, ArgP, v) to describe the size, shape, tilt, swivel, twist, and position of a satellite in an inertial coordinate frame. The size (a) and shape (e) of any orbit are defined by the semi-major axis and eccentricity respectively. These parameters define the orbit piece which is attached to the center of the whizWheel. A highly eccentric orbit is provided here to help with visualization.
The size or shape orbit can be modified if desired, but not recommended. The outer square of the WhizWheel represents the inertial coordinate frame on the plane of the elliptic. The first of the inner gimbals represents the location of the right ascension of the accenting node (RAAN). Simply swivel the n vector (pointing to the node) from I (the inertial axis on the outer frame) by the RAAN in degrees. The inclination, or tilt of an orbit, is represented by the next innermost gimbals. Simply tilt the orbital plane by your inclination (i) in degrees -- press down on the 270 degree simple for an accurate representation of the direction of tilt. The angle to perigee (the point of closest approach to the earth) is visualized by twisting the attached orbit so that the perigee points to the angle defined by the argument of perigee (ArgP). Once all of these COEs have been simulated on the WhizWheel you have successfully defined the simple orbital motion of a satellite around Earth. The final COE is the true anomaly (v), which defines the position of a satellite at a specific moment in time as measured from perigee. In simple orbital motion, this is the only COE which changes with time.

For a low Earth orbit a satellite may complete an orbit in roughly 90 minutes. But, out at geosynchronous orbit the satellite takes 24 hours to complete an orbit. The WhizWheel is a useful tool for visualizing any satellite in Earth orbit.
Background infomration More information on satellite motion and Classical Orbital Elements (COEs) can be found in Seller's book: Understanding Space.

This is Day 17 of my collection of printable equations. To see the whole collection, go to: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227210 This will be last printable equation for a while. Real life's caught up and I don't have enough time. I may post a new equation once in a while, but I'm not sure. In a few days, I will post the source code I used to generate the oscad files. Continuing the series of polynomials today, with y = ax^3 + bx^2. Details:
  • units are in mm
  • Range(x) = -55 to 45
  • a = 50/(45^3), b = 50/(45^2)
All files can be printed without support. Photos shown were printed on a Replicator 2 and sliced using the standard setting on Makerware.

title: Mr. Chip-E
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi everyone, this is my remix of the biped robot, Chip-E, for the Chip-E Remix Challenge. I designed al the accesories and modifications with Tinkercad, I picked up the STL files from the Robot Geek account (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795648) and based on them to create the Mr. Chip-E.

I chose the idea of Mr. and Mrs. Potato Head because I think this makes funny and orginal the Chip-E case by letting anyone to modify and create his own accesories for the robot. You can make him look like Batman, Superman,etc.

I've included a lot of accesories but I want the people to feel free to remix it and post the final result.

I've also used the Batman logo from DylWall (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:512971), the Wonder Woman logo from TK3DPrinting (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2405812), the Superman logo from Sebastianrosca (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:101563) and the Captain America's Shield from 2be3D (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1526546).

The arms are supposed to move by a servomotor but I don't know how the electronics should be, so if someone knows how to please leave a comment telling me how, im not used to electronics.

Please also chekout my other design for the challenge (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2433614).

Hope you like it and enjoy the printing :)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

In many of the accessories you may need sanding because the supports sometimes leave some leftovers.

You can paint the accessories with acrilyc paint, I'd used it in other things I've printed and it worked pretty well. For best results give it two layers of paint. Or you can just use colored filament.

This is an 18mm scale infanty fighting vehicle I designed for use in war and roleplaying games.

In particular, I wanted to create a vehicle player characters in an RPG might encounter and reasonably overcome (i.e. not a main battle tank). This IFV boasts twin lasers on its turret, as well twin forward-mounted machine guns. I envision the lasers as being mainly used for automatically shooting down drones and incoming missiles that threaten the vehicle. That said, I'm sure they'd do find against a variety of targets. The side armor is designed so that it can be used as cover for infantry units even if the IFV itself is disabled.

Pictured with the IFV is one of dutchmogul's colonial soldiers.

description.text:
First observed on Taurus VII, the Alien hovership remains a mystery. This is a replica with what information we currently have. They float 3 to 5m above the ground, and the upper surfaces of the domed hull and turret are living and capable of some self repair. The turret can rotate 360' and the gun has limited movement within its eye socket. The gun is of particle weapon type, known to the troops as a "Kermit shooter" and is very effective out to long range.
There were many battles on various systems between the Alien Hover tanks and the Federation BT700s tanks, and they proved more than a match for the Federation vehicle. They were faster, able to cross any terrain, and their gun was more effective. However they have no shielding, but do have heavy armour and a self repair capacity which is lacking on the earlier Federation vehicles.
Although still classified, some information has been released. Only one Alien crew is needed for each vehicle, and it cannot easily exit the vehicle, being sealed inside it when it is built. Damaged Hover tanks which have suffered too much damage for its self repair capacity become a dark coffin for the alien, who apparently can live on for many Centric Months, in darkness slowly starving to death.

title: Amazon Echo Alexa Fancy Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Are you searching for a solid, sturdy, well-designed wall mount for your Amazon Alexa? Did you find the other peasant wall mounts available to be beneath you? Well then my good sir, I present the fancy wall mount, made specifically for the discerning Amazon enthusiast.

This wall mount was designed high in the mountains of Tuscany. Expertly modeled, this wall mount was hand crafted by the finest Italian artisans while they were hand fed Sangiovese grapes. The finished product is a magnificent display of taste, quality, and art perfect for your villa or chalet.

Suggested print settings:
Highly detailed/High Res model best represented at a 0.1mm layer height, but quite functional and acceptable at standard 0.3mm (as pictured). The print orientation is as-modeled, with the wall mount face flat against the build plate. Limited supports will be necessary inside the decorative bracing. An 85 degree support cutoff for a few limited areas inside the print is sufficient. 20% infill is sufficient for support.

Suggested hardware for mount:
The wall mount utilizes (2) 1-1/2" #8 flat head wood screws. It is essential that the top screw head seat into the countersunk pocket to prevent binding/inability to seat. The length and type of screw (be it drywall anchors, etc.) is irrelevant, provided it is a flat head screw as visible in the preview photos.

Additional info:
This mount has very low tolerances, and is meant to grab your Echo extremely tight to prevent tips/falls. Because of this, the mount does not require an upper attachment point as some of the other peasant wall mounts incorporate.

title: Low-friction Filament Reel Mount for Makerbot

description.text:
I had a problem with prints stopping in the middle of a print.  I read online that some people were able to solve this with a low-friction mounting method for the filament.  
Looking through the other things in thingiverse, I got the idea to use airsoft BB's as the balls in the bearing.  These are low-cost, smooth, and I already have them by the thousands.  
I simply made the bearing mountable to the Makerbot.  
I consider this design complete, although there probably could be improvements.  
Pictures shown are of the first iteration.  I slightly revised the files for better bearing retention and use of space, but the first revision works well, so I'm not re-printing.

You will need:
--- Several airsoft 6mm BB's (I used 17)
--- Screws and nuts that you already have on your makerbot - I used 2, but there is the option of having 4
--- The two pieces that are printed 1) Print one base and one cap. The cap has an undercut, but it is angled at 45 degrees and very printable on most machines.
2) Mount to your machine using the screws and nuts (see picture). This will only work when mounted on the TOP of your Makerbot with this particular bearing b/c it is simply held in-place by gravity.
3) Place all BB's in trough.
4) Place the groove-side of the cap on top of the BB's.
5) Place your filament reel on top of the bearing.
6) Enjoy low-friction printing!

comments.text: This worked much better than I expected, it turns quite easily.  My reels are different sizes, so I just cut the reel interface off and then made and adapter for my reel.  It had the benefit of making the top race easier to print - no overhangs and I could print with the groove side up

title: Tower Pro 9G Micro Servo for Arduino

description.text:
This is a solid model of the Tower Pro 9g Micro Servo that comes in standard Arduino kits. I'm working on a few 3D assemblies that will use this servo, but I couldn't find this exact servo on GrabCad or 3D Content Central.

I have also uploaded the SOLIDWORKS 2016 files along with STL's so you can open the solid model and see if it will work with your components. I tried to model this to the 1000th of an inch, but I could be off by a few thousandths in the X, Y, and Z directions. However, if you were to print this thing or insert this component into a 3D modeling assembly, it would be an accurate enough representation to allow for decisions about component placement and installation options. The three small conjoined cylinders on the side of the servo represent the wiring bundle.

Please let me know if you have any questions or notice something that needs to be changed.

description.text:
So I tried the other over the top of the printer spool holder but had some issues with roll back tugging on the filament so I designed this one. It seems to be doing very well.

To make it work you also need to have the Spool Bolt and Nut, or something similar with the hole that just fits the threaded rod. I use the one at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1624641/#files which I think is awesome.

Once printed just use two of the nuts that came with it, thread on so that it sits in the locking section of the print, and the second goes on top of that to provide a minimal amount of friction for pulling the filament. After that put your spool on and thread the filament through the built-in guide. plus it mounts right with the display and replaces the spacers.

I have made about 6 points using this version thus far and seems to be working better for me than the vertical style with no roll back yanking on the filament.

***8/15/17 Added the file for version 7 which adds an extra support layer to the arm.

***9/1/17 I noticed some turning of the nut with different filament spools so I suggest adding a 608 bearing on the threaded rod above the nut and below the spool.

title: Ultra Light Bowden Carriage W/ LED

description.text:
3/17/2018 - I am discontinuing development of this mount. I have made 1 more fan duct. Its an edit. It is 3/4 circle. That will be the last thing I will be uploading. This is a good mount. It works good. I have been using it for some time. But I have a new mount I am developing which will not be released until complete.

8/21/2017 A friend of mine downloaded the new fan duct, and said it fits perfect.. Waiting for word on how well it works...

8/20/2017 Just finished the fan duct I had been working on that is specifically made for this carriage. I HAVE NOT PRINTED IT YET.. So I am not sure how it will print, but the way it was designed was to let the most amount of air come through for the best cooling I can get.. We will see if it works...

8/13/2017 I have added a quick chop up of a fan duct that fits good enough but works well. The original can be found at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1954001 . Mine is a remix of that one. Also, I have been Printing with the latest version of the carriage and it is fantastic. I am able to print a amazing speeds for the Anet with excellent quality. It's awesome. I will be uploading a standard cap for the hotend soon as well.

8/3/2017 On the 18mm sensor version.. updated it so that the nuts will spinon the sensor.. they hit the body of the carriage.. although there was enough play in them to make it work..

8/01/2017 I have printed and fully assembled the latest version which is uploaded. It works beautifully. I have a blurry pic of the setup.. Will get a better one. It is perfect.. There are some tweaks that can be done that are more ascetic than functional. I am uploading my 30mm to 40mm adapter because that works great too. It's as short as it can be without it bot working right. My goal is to put together a package for the UL bowden carriage. Will includ a carriage, fan duct, cap, 30 to 40 adapter, and whatever else I use. I still have to finish the cap. As well I am going to put in a groove for the nuts on the 18mm sensor, because I made it so close you cannot spin the nuts.. however you can make it work as is.

7/30/17 About 12% of printing left of the latest version on the 18mm sensor. Print looks really good. I have pics of the mark 2, but my phone wouldn't upload them fsr. Checked real quick while it was printing and the sensor fit with just enough play. The only thing left is to re design the e3d v6 mount. I want to add 2 more screws. So a total of 2 to each side, to maximize the clamping stay. After time these screws get loose, and the plastic wears, so 2 more screws will help. Have to redesign the cap.. right now the cap from the standard "customizable bowden carriage" fits. That is why I do not have a cap yet. Soon... Once this print is done, I am going to try it out and see how it works.

7/30/2017. Printed the mark 2. I didn't compensate for shrink enough for the 18mm sensor.. few other things I have to fix that I can see. But the zip tie mounts are good. I printed it as fast as the printer could go. Print came out great. No support. It weighs only 45-46 grams. Awesome. At .1 layer height, 50% infill, it took a little over 5 hours to make. Pretty fast for the quality. Tonight I will tweak and up load.

7/28/2017 I uploaded the new version. (Mark 2). Changelog: Fixed zip tie mounts. Removed brace as it is useless, un needed and often would print poorly. I also added another size for the sensor mount. There is now a 12mm and 18mm mount size.

7/27/2017 **(MARK 1 was Removed) this is the mark 1. It printed great but I found other issues to address in the mark 2 I am cadding. First.. I mad the holes for the zip ties to close tolerance. With very little shrinkage from peinting, they won't fit. I have to play with the angle of the LED. Also, I the mark 1, the only thing I didn't ground up design was the mount for the end. But I am really signing this ground up as well. I wI'll be addressing a common issue with the original design this carriage was ispired by. Loosening screws and wobbling hot ends. There are a few more changes comming, so stay tuned.

UL Bowden carriage with LED. I had been taking the basic bowden carriage that has been floating around and customizing it like most, but it was just sloppy after you cut it up and tack things on it.

So I built one from scratch. It is inspired by the very same one mentioned above, but is completely from the ground up.

I also made it Ultra Light. (Basically big holes in where there can be to make it lighter) For printer heads, the lighter the better. The original carriage works great. I wanted it to be lighter. I think it also looks cool.

I am currently printing the first one. I will post pictures of the finished product. I did not make a cap. The standard one from the for mentioned will work. eventually I will make one from scratch and post it up.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

50%

Notes:

All parts are printed at .1mm layer height. I used PLA. Support is not needed.

Buliding it Ground up.

I had been remixing current bowden carriages that are out there. 1 in particular that has been remixed so many times, I am not sure where it started. It served it's purpose, however was lacking in my needs. So basically cadded my own version from scratch. It is close to the same measurements but not quite. It fits the Anet perfectly. The Idea was to make a carriage that was light to help reduce jerk, and to integrate a level sensor. I use an inductive so that it will detect Glass as that is what I print on. I had used capacitive sensor and was able to get it to detect the bed underneath, but it was troublesome. I also made a carriage with a 12mm sensor mount in case someone wanted to use a capacitive sensor as opposed to an inductive. I also wanted an LED to shine on the part while printing so I could see what was going on without using my phone as a flashlight.

I used TinkerCad to design it. I like Tinkercad. Works good for an online cad. I made a lot of measurements, and started over several times before it started to take shape.

Currently I only have tweaking to do, and have a working prototype that works perfect.

title: Ampel - Mini Stoplight by Montiey remix

description.text:
This is an extended remix of Montiey stoplight.

I have split the provided top shell part into pieces that can be printed separately.
The now separated flanged sun shields are inserted to the openings from the frontside.
They are glued together with the case and the internal transparent neutral white inserts.
Replace the inserts with coloured foil if needed.

Update:
added pic with sample pcb screwed on
added a plan schematic for low current LED shining bright consuming 3mA current only.
As you might think, this is a little bit of joking.

The LED's CAN NOT FIGHT THE SUNLIGHT.
PUT THE STOP LIGHT IN A SHADOWED AREA.

https://www.reichelt.de/?ARTICLE=21627&PROVID=2788&wt_mc=amc141526782519998&gclid=CLC4_-jSh9UCFUK7Gwodd90DQA

Have added two flat inserts 29.8mm dia (closed, hollowed).
Have put the fat backcase 50x130x30mm to the universe.
Just in case you are going to make something bigger ;-)

Have the case in two versions:

  1. the flat has the LED's only (stl file for download)
  2. fat thing that can hold the electronics and a battery as well.
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2434221

The depicted red and green front inserts can be omitted if the LED's are not bright enough.
Otherwise a coloured transparent thin foil can be added inside the housing.

Ask the local hobby store for Windradfolie oder Bastelfolie, nonadhesive preferred, 0.4mm thickness is sufficiently enough for the stop light.
Example:
https://www.modulor.de/bastelmappe-fensterfolie-farbig-transparent-s-0-1-mm-230-x-330-7-blatt.html

They can be had in different size, thickness and many colours.
Take that if you have no other than black filament by hand , he ;-)

For calculating the (shunt-) resistors look at
http://www.spaceflakes.de
This site has an interactive calculator for exactly that purpose.
As a sample I have added a plan for the low current LED's I have purchased.

Now the stop light shell has evolved into a universal system of parts for several purpose cases.

Changes, additions I have designed and made:
Have simplified the shape of the shell parts,
removed the switch hole,
designed thin and thick LED insert plates, that can be exchanged / adapted easily to LED that has other shapes.
designed intermediate open case frame,
designed a big bottom case part derived from the provided rear shell,
added mountholes with captured nuts to the backside plates,
added a few screw on posts to the backplate for holding something like a PCB.
added a few screw on posts to the frontplate for holding something like a PCB, i.e. a thin plate with surface mounted LED, tactile switches,...
Have added a cable go through to the fat case.
It has the same "Stopfen" that I have made for my Notausschalter-case:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2412076

comments.text: Looks like a Taz 6. I just got mine two weeks ago. Would you mind explaining how you do the filament swapping?
comments.author: wztk

comments.text:
Yep its a TAZ6
For me I design and/or pick models that lend themselves to multiple colors via different layer heights.
In CURA you can set a pause at Z layer height pugin to stop at a given height. So for this model I printed it with a scale of 2.0 in the Z-axis and set the plugin to stop at 2.01 mm that way I am sure the 2 mm layer height is done. Once paused the head moves to safe location, I swap the filament and then load the new color filament. For clean transitions I carefully push the filament in to purge out the old color -- pushing gently until the new color is coming out cleanly. I make sure the nozzle is clear, I re-apply the clamp to hold the filament in place and resume the print. You repeat this process for each color you want to add.
NOTE: I find that cura has a bug with the pause at z height plugin wherein it doesn't recognize anything after the first stop so usually I have to sit there to wait and manually pause for filament changes #2 or later or I have to hand edit the gcode.

title: Rua (Face-turning Rhombic Dodecahedron)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Rua

The Rua was originally invented by Matt Shepit on the Twistypuzzles forum. It is a face-turning rhombic dodecahedron with the same cut depth as a Helicopter cube.

This model is a functioning replica of the puzzle. It is the first "complex" puzzle that I designed. As proud as I am of this puzzle, it has quite a few flaws, and requires a significant amount of post-processing to function. I am currently re-making this puzzle with totally different internals, which is why I'm releasing my old files. This particular design is provided "as is" and will not be revised.

This particular design has only been printed in PLA, and has not been tested with ABS. However, I have no reason to believe that it wouldn't work with ABS.

Parts Roster

NOTE: Some of the parts were split in half to allow easy printing without supports. The two halves are designated "A" and "B" in the STL's.

NOTE: Two files for the core are included. The ABS core has slightly smaller screw holes.

1x core (ABS).stl OR 1x core (PLA).stl
12x center.stl (Hidden center pieces)
24x EdgeA.stl & 24x EdgeB.stl (Hidden edge pieces)
24x TriangleA.stl & 24x TriangleB.stl (Triangular face pieces)
8x 3CornerA.stl & 8x 3CornerB.stl (3-fold corner pieces)
6x 4CornerStem.stl & 6x 4CornerBase.stl & 6x 4CornerCap.stl (4-fold corner pieces)

Optional: 12x Tiles.stl (Tiles for the puzzle)

Additional Hardware: This puzzle requires 12 Dayan screws and springs for 57mm cubes, available for purchase at thecubicle.

Printer Brand:

Tinkertine Studio

Printer:

Ditto +

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Post-Processing

Parts need a significant amount of sanding for the puzzle to be playable. In general, the fillets on this puzzle were not large enough, so in many places, sharp angles at intersections need to be clipped off or sanded down. If you make this, it is advised to break in the internal Helicopter cube mechanism before attempting to insert the outer pieces.

description.text:
This is a one-two hours project and it turned out great. I made a couple versions, but I think most 3D printers and settings will work well on this version. Enjoy!!

I got a couple requests that the articulated ball joints are great, but they kept falling off.
To make it safer around children, I made the articulated ball joints not fall off.

Special thanks to Andrew Lindsey and Solid_Alexei.

title: Aus3D IR Z-Probe v1.4 Mount for Stock Anet A8

description.text:
This is a mount for the Aus3D Z-Probe version 1.4 (http://aus3d.com.au/ir-z-probe) for a stock Anet A8 printer.

It slides down between the extruder stepper motor and is screwed on using the screws that hold the X-carriage on to the bottom linear bearing (see pictures). You will need to dismantle the X-carriage to install it.

The Z-probe is attached to the right-hand side using 2 short M3 bolts and nuts, with tracks to allow the probe to be moved to the height that suits your build.

The side that the probe attaches to was a little fragile in my first design but I managed to get mine working, I've since added more material to try and strengthen it a bit.

Feel free to modify or change as you see fit, I've included the .blend file for anyone who wants to mess around with it, maybe you can do a better job at it than me!

Bonus video of it working! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Lc1PLIHWoA

description.text:
Inspired on the PhantomX I wanted to turn Chip into something else, adding a bunch of new functionalities to the robot.

To simplify a little bit, I went with the quadruped robot idea, so I got more inspiration from the allbot robot, another free design on thingiverse.

I had to modify the servo mount to fit MG90S servos, that are metal geared servos, to allow the extra load that my chip-e would have.
The original design only fits small plastic gear servos.

I added holes to the side and top of the chip, making possible to increase the number of modification using the allbot platform, it is possible to create arms, different types of legs, etc...

I also changed the original chip design to allow easier assembly, no more screws are needed to the top part, they all fit together with small 3d printed tabs.
I changed the lcd to the mouth to add a little bit of more realistic robot look.
Everything can be printed without support.

Key new functionalities are:

  • Custom remote controller with two lcd's
  • Right eye of CHIP stream video in real time to the bigger lcd
  • Small lcd get information back from the robot, can alert battery status, sensor informations, etc
  • Capability to play wav audio files using Adafruit Audio FX Sound Board
  • High power 3W RGB led on the right eye (Pixie)
  • Laser aimed Custom nerf cannon powered by a high pressure co2 cartridge, handled by a solenoid valve.
  • Total of 16 servos to allow movements of the legs, neck, and cannon.

Firmware is also opensource:
https://github.com/vitormhenrique/chip-e

CHIP-E II: new design, same concept.
This version is a new challenge for those who were able to make him walk and dance. It’s a new design that seeks to attract more people to the world of programming in a simple and funny way.
Upgrades:

  • The main change were the feet, which now are looking to the front and the heels were redesigned to allow a 90° turn.
  • Legs and body only suffered little esthetical changes, pendulant arms were added to move along when Chip-E does.
  • The lower part of the body now has leds that can be configured to switch on and off according to programming.
  • In order to avoid changing the electronical mechanism, the internal dimensions were kept in.

I hope you enjoy and have fun with this new design of CHIP-E II.

It can hold up to 7" tablet and smartphones. you can print it downscaled to >96% if you don't use cover or case.

This is a ratcheting brake for a Wilder winder commonly used for indoor free flight models. It's a bolt on design that requires no permanent modification to the winder. You only need a 6-32 x 1-1/4" pan head screw, and two M3 x 8mm flat head screws to assemble and install it.

The gear is held in place by the head of the original screw that holds the shaft collar in place. Remove the screw, slide the gear over the collar, and re-install the screw.

To assemble the brake, insert the slide into the lock, and then screw the mount to the slide with the M3 screws.

Installing the assembly only requires removing the original 6-32 screw from the top of the winder, and then attaching the brake to the winder with the 6-32 x 1-1/4" screw.

The parts are modeled with some clearance, and on my printer the brake slides up and down with just enough friction to hold it in place. The model is mostly parametric, so if someone needs more or less clearance let me know and I can post modified STL files. I don't believe this is necessary though if you have a reasonably well tuned printer.

title: Simple Dual Hotend Mounting Plate For Rostock MAX

description.text:
This dual hotend mounting plate bolts directly to the existing hotend mounting plate on the Rostock MAX.  It mounts the two hotends some 25mm apart (center-to-center) and holds them perpendicular to the build plate.  The left hotend is offset from center -12.5mm on X and 0 on Y.  The right hotend is offset 12.5mm on X and 0 on Y.  
The hotends mounting holes are sized for seemeCNC hotends (appx. 11mm); the tolerances of the holes are "slip fit."  The hotends are held in place with their normal nuts.  The flats at the top of the mounting holes extend just above (0.2mm) the existing hotend mounting plate, allowing the nuts to be tightened on the hotends securely.  
The second photo shows the first test print for the mounting plate while the print was in progress.  Minor software correction of the X and Y offsets (+.1mm X axis and -.3mm Y axis on the Second extruder) achieved perfect registration.  The "drool" that you see in the print was pretty well resolved by adjusting retraction when an extruder was taken out of active print mode (this is a slicer settings issue).

This is a very simple and rigid print.  I used Cura 14.01 to slice the .stl file.  The print was done with a .5 nozzle.  Layers are .2mm.  The shell and top/bottom are all .6mm thick.  I used a 30% fill density.  The first two layers were printed at 240°.  The remaining layers were printed at 230°.

comments.text: Heads up for anyone that wants to upgrade their Rostock Max with dual extrusion and use the original rounded hotend nozzle! They now use a pointed hotend nozzle. If you have the rounded one, you will want to buy TWO nozzles so that you have the same height. That or...yeah....make your own if you are brave/foolish/skilled enough. Overall, you may want to have multiple sizes of nozzles anyways. Just be careful to not damage the hotend while you swap nozzles.
comments.author: nathanstenzel

comments.text: I was just wondering that. Maybe if you get one that matches the original they are already sized the same?
comments.author: carterm

comments.text: How do you adjust the height of the hotends so they are the same?
comments.author: WWC

comments.text: Hi, WWC.  That's a tough question.  With the Steve's Extruder you can tighten/loosen one of the nozzles to get it to match the Z-height of the other nozzle.  It is not a perfect solution but it seems to work pretty well - the nozzle will not move or work loose if you use this technique to effect a minor height adjustment.  I have also cut washers from .001" thick shim stock and installed them on the threaded end of the extruder before inserting the extruder in the mounting plate; obviously, a single washer will lower the nozzle Z-height by .001".  Good luck!  - Bill
comments.author: WWC

author: geul

description.text:
Sorry, but this thing isn't about British claymation. ;)

Rather, this thing is for creating rubber grommits commonly to seal pipes or wires passing through a sealed container. You can also do a plug which is just a grommit with no hole.

It is also a test of my "auto units" library, so for many values you can type in most anything you want and it should "do the right thing".

You can either print the part directly using flexible filament or create a 3-piece mold for silicone or oogoo. (Don't forget to use a mold release like petroleum jelly)

In the picture I used the mold method (stl included). It didn't work too great. I think it didn't admit enough air for straight silicone to cure well. It took well over 48 hours and was still fragile enough to be damaged on extraction. Using oogoo instead would probably work better.

(If you aren't familiar with oogoo, here is a good write-up:
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute/)

Please take particular care when removing the rockets from the build plate as the stress caused when releasing the legs can cause the bottom of the central part of the model to break off. (If possible release the centre section first)

I would advise to print the porthole on a raft at lower scales.

title: C1 Chaser FC Mount Behind Spar

description.text: If you want to run large batteries, the front mount FC gets in the way unless you raise it really high up in the body. The easier solution is to move the FC behind the spar. This FC mount will sit flush with the ledge the center section lid rests on when installed. I plan to make a couple other versions with different levels of drop-down built in in case more stack height is needed for a Multirotor PDB or whatever.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.13125

Infill:

25% 'lines'

Notes:

If you print this vertically you will not need supports but it won't hurt to print a brim to make sure the part stays on the bed while printing. Alternatively you could print this flat wiht support under the outside 'wings'. Your call! I printed this part with PETG but other materials are probably fine too.

Once printed you will either want to screw a M3 screw into each of the four FC mount holes being careful to keep the screw perpendicular to the plate to cut the threads for the standoffs. Alternatively you can drill the holes out and use M3 bolts / nuts / whatever to secure the FC.

I prefer to cut the threads.

This is a box to mount a Raspberry Pi 3 (https://www.raspberrypi.org/) and a Picamera (https://www.raspberrypi.org/products/camera-module-v2/) to the frame of an helloBEEprusa (https://beeverycreative.com/hellobeeprusa-3d-printer/) from Beeverycreative to form an Octopi (https://octopi.octoprint.org/), the Raspberry Pi version of the famous print server OctoPrint (http://octoprint.org/).
I added four LEDs to light the scene and a downstep DC/DC converter to power the board.
I used four white high efficiency LEDs and three 1/4W 270 Ohm resistors to connect to the 24V helloBEEprusa power supply.
I found a very small DC/DC step-down converter to reduce the 24V power supply to the 5v needed by the Raspberry Pi. I used an LM2596 4.5V-28V a 0.8V-20V STEP DOWN BUCK CONVERTER DC DC 3 A marked D-Sun, like this one from e-bay: http://www.ebay.it/itm/Super-Mini-3A-DC-DC-Converter-Step-Down-Adjustable-Power-Supply-buck-Module-/122155531744?hash=item1c71097de0:g:7tcAAOSws5pZJiw1 that is very cheap and small.
To build the object I started from a very nice box by Normand: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:410003
I used the "no logo" version and modified the base to use 3MA cylinder head srews.
For the camera, I used the camera box from the case by cyul: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1394500
I completely changed the mount.
I used FreeCAD to design the parts
My slicer had this as non-manifold, but it worked after sending it through netfabb

Variable size spool holder box, a knock off of Prusa's multi material kit spool holder.

This is an excellent holder for a dry box, as it's sturdy, has a direct feed into a bowden tube that you can then run through a side wall, and you can swap out individual spools without disturbing the rest.

The DXF files provided assume a 3.25mm panel thickness (which is roughly what both my 1/8" birch ply and acrylic measured) and have no kerf compensation, which should be fine as the printed parts provide the mechanical connection. Each DXF file has 2 cutting layers, CUTOUTS and PERIMETER. Cut them in that order.

For different or more precise panel thicknesses and/or kerf compensation, use Fusion 360 to adjust the panel_thickness user variable and "DXF for Laser" by Ross Korsky ( https://apps.autodesk.com/FUSION/en/Detail/Index?id=7634902334100976871 ) to re-export the DXF files with Kerf compensation.

Fasteners are M3 with socket cap heads.
Bearings are 608 skate bearing.
Rods are 8mm x 108mm (5/16" x 4 1/4" will do in a pinch).
Feed tubes are PTFE bowden tubes.

FAQ:

Q. Why design a knock off?
A. The laser cut parts are missing from the git repo for the multi-material kit. Since I was redoing the laser cut parts I did the rest as well (so I could modify and model it all together).

Q. Where do you get the rods?
A. I had TAP Plastics cut up some Acrylic Rod for me in 108mm lengths. You want 8mm but can settle for 5/16" rod or tubing.

This iPad Stand was designed to be easy to print and awesome for someone to use. It's design contains a handle for easy carrying, a lip at the bottom to hold the iPad in place, and holes and cutaways to help reduce material use.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed without any supports and turns out nice. 75% infill due to the fact, that it has to stem all the load of the printer. Less maybe also possible without problems but: why? :-P

title: Simple Center Support for TEVO Black Widow Prusa Clone

description.text:
Simple Single Center Supports for TEVO Black Widow. I am that kind of 3D Printing newbee who is horrible impatient so when I saw this center support blocks with print times over 5 h I decided to design my own supports - minimalistic and fast to print.

I made 12 of them to lock my printer to a 20mm wooden board and it came out very heavily secured.

Fits thight under my printer. You may have to measure and scale some mm for your Black Widow. Give it a try.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

75

Notes:

Printed without any supports and turns out nice. 75% infill due to the fact, that it has to stem all the load of the printer. Less maybe also possible without problems but: why? :-P

YouTube video here: https://youtu.be/fy0t_MzYuiA

This is comprised of 2 kits:

  1. RPZero version which has 2 sets of sides in case you want to add a stereo 66mm speakers, and normal set. It also has 2 tops, one normal and one with a USB hole that fits the USB extension that is included with the pi.

  2. RPi2/3 version wich is the same as the original box.

BOTH KITS are to be assembled with M3x12mm screws and the microphone can be done with M3x6mm. Speaker is M4x6mm.

This is an altered version for this: (So full credit for the original idea)
https://www.raspberrypi.org/forums/viewtopic.php?f=114&t=182803&sid=c6adf8d974e44c92f3d45ed04fc782df
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/fy0t_MzYuiA" ></iframe>

Just in time for Valentine's I've updated my Heart Gears. These use my new snap pin library, so they print more reliably and are much easier to assemble. I've also included three different gear ratios so you can choose how much frustration you wish to impart. Assembly instructions can be found in this video: http://youtu.be/O-qwmRwOpFQ Alternate instructions are here https://jig.space/viewer?jig=427, courtesy of greenlig. Pretty cool system for making interactive 3D instructions - check it out. I didn't make this design Customizer-friendly, because there aren't really changeable parameters. However, the OpenSCAD file has been rewritten and greatly simplified to make it easier to cut gears out of your own shape. I'm always excited to see new derivative gear mashups.

Hopefully the video makes assembly pretty clear. I always recommend greasing the pins to keep it turning smoothly without squeaking. I use white lithium grease, but anything that doesn't melt plastic should work.   
The heart plates are named by their gear ratio, so 1-2 is 1 : 2, etc. 1-2 has a period of one revolution, while 2-3 is two and 5-6 takes five revolutions, so don't give up. If you need the parts separately, many free mesh editors and slicers can separate plated parts. Or you can export them from the OpenSCAD script.

title: TEVO Black Widow Frame Support IKEA Ekby Stödis based

description.text:
Due to my imaptience I refused to print frame supports for hours when I can get 4 heavy duty ones for 2 bucks at local swedish furniture dealer.

If you use IKEA Ekby Stödis console/brackets to stabilize your printer, you might need some underlay. Especially when corner brackets are installed.

Simple Design, easy to use. I fixed mine to a 20mm wooden plate with them.
